title: Exhaustion by compact sets
summary: In mathematics, especially general topology and analysis, an exhaustion by compact sets[1] of a topological space X {\displaystyle X} is a nested sequence of compact subsets K i {\displaystyle K_{i}} of X {\displaystyle X} (i.e. K 1 ⊆ K 2 ⊆ K 3 ⊆ ⋯ {\displaystyle K_{1}\subseteq K_{2}\subseteq K_{3}\subseteq \cdots } ), such that K i {\displaystyle K_{i}} is contained in the interior of K i + 1 {\displaystyle K_{i+1}} , i.e. K i ⊆ int ( K i + 1 ) {\displaystyle K_{i}\subseteq {\text{int}}(K_{i+1})} for each i {\displaystyle i} and X = ⋃ i = 1 ∞ K i {\displaystyle X=\bigcup _{i=1}^{\infty }K_{i}} .  A space admitting an exhaustion by compact sets is called exhaustible by compact sets.
